data.title: Stage selected lines stages only big chunks for line deletions

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
From @kachkaev
 I can't find out how to select just two deleted lines out of 5 going sequentially and stage only the ones I want. Any time I select something and click that menu item, the whole block gets staged. The same happens when unstaging.

data.title: How to easily move around my code
data.body:
It is not a bug report nor a feature request, I have one question though and I didn't find where to ask about. Sorry, if it is not a good place to ask these kind of questions.

In ST3 and Atom there is a Easy-Motion plugin to go to anywhere around my code super easily with just few key strokes. Of course this type of feature is provided by plugin ant not available in the editors out of the box. But for VSCode I was searching for such plugin in market place since few months hoping someday it will be available :) but still cannot find so I am here to ask:

**What is too bad about Easy-Motion like feature and nobody is interested in creating one for VSCode?**
**Is there any simpler way to achieve the same in VSCode ?**

data.title: Enable configuring Typescript Beta Language service
data.body: As Typescript language service support is built-in, users cannot enable Typescript language service from an alpha/beta/preview version. Although they can install and use the beta version for building the project. Please enable this configuration, so that language service can use preview/beta compilers, if installed on machine.

data.title: CSS inlining warnings in build

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
Found this in my `gulp watch`:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22350/16944956/2d46ef46-4da3-11e6-8c22-306982d1b721.png)
- Is this really necessary to be ALL CAPS?
- I noticed it is the only reference to `console` in the whole css loader plugin, shouldn't the errors be sent back to whoever calls `optimize` instead? That guy would then print it according to what's expected (just like in the lines right afterwards, that contain `[optimizer]`).
- Also, is consolidating the rules really the fix, at the expense of making the CSS less readable?

data.title: Missing output with clear then scroll
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: OSX Yosemite 10.10.5

This could be a mismatch in opinion for the behavior of `clear` or `Ctrl-L` and scrolling (as I believe I've seen this behavior on a Linux Mint machine), but here's my problem:

Let's say I have a lot of output from a certain command in the integrated terminal (mine uses bash). If I enter `clear` or `Ctrl-L`, the terminal gets cleared, which is good! However, if I scroll up, a chunk of output from the verbose command is missing (seems directly related to the height of the terminal window).

What I expected: Using _my_ default bash terminal on my Mac, the screen gets cleared, but if I scroll up, **all** the output is still there.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open the integrated terminal (I supply the `-l` option in `settings.json` in order to use my `~/.bash_profile`)
2. Run a command with lengthy ouput (e.g. `ruby -e 'puts "START";100.times { |n| puts "Line #{ n + 1 }" };puts "END"'`)
3. Enter `clear`
4. Scroll up

With the terminal occupying around 80% of my screen height, I only got output of that Ruby command to around line 50 (i.e. I never see "END" after clearing).

If this is just a matter of terminal opinion, it might be nice to have an option in `settings.json` to define the clear/scroll behavior.

data.title: Side loaded extensions don't prompt when outdated.
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.3.1, 1.4.0-insiders
- OS Version:Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Download ESLint extension version 0.10.17 using URL: https://dbaeumer.gallery.vsassets.io/_apis/public/gallery/publisher/dbaeumer/extension/vscode-eslint/0.10.17/assetbyname/Microsoft.VisualStudio.Services.VSIXPackage
2. Rename .zip to .vsix and install the .vsix with File > Open File...
3. Restart VS Code and check that installed version is 0.10.17.  The current Marketplace version is 0.10.18 so should be prompted to update.  Check Show Outdated Extensions, nothing.

This also happens if you side load 0.10.18 and then change the version to 0.10.17.  VS Code doesn't detect the extension as outdated.

If you install 0.10.18 from Extension view, and change the version number to 0.10.17, it will be detected as outdated.

data.title: Issue while repainting in cmd console
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.3.1 (e6b4afa53e9c0f54edef1673de9001e9f0f547ae, 2016-07-12T13:35:06.227Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.10586

The following steps are probably the longest way of doing this, but this is what I did.
You can run any script that periodically repaints a certain line. (e.g. progress bar/percentage).

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open the console window (ctrl+`)
2. Launch powershell
3. Use AzCopy.exe to copy a lot of files to azure blob storage. This command usually will list just a single line that will keep repaining with new info:

Finished: 555 file(s), transfer speed: 66.84 MB/s

instead of one line, it will spit a new line every few seconds (I assume the refresh cycle).

Finished: 555 file(s), transfer speed: 66.84 MB/s
Finished: 558 file(s), transfer speed: 68.31 MB/s
...

This can probably be done with other commands as well.

data.title: Handle events on the terminal panel DOM element from within panel
data.body: Currently events are handled in each terminal instance, this means that event handlers go off for each terminal instances for an event on the terminal panel.

data.title: Support F# Syntax Highlighting Inside Markdown Fenced Code Blocks
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.3.1 - OS Version: Windows 10 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open a Markdown (`.md`) file. 2. Add a codeblock between triple backtick code block markers, such as: 1. Notice that there is no syntax highlighting for the code block (different color for the block, that is). This seems like a regression because a couple of version ago this was working. **NOTE:** Disregard the `fsharp` language identifier. If you remove it, there is still no syntax highlight for the block.

data.title: Explorer: allow to expand a sub-tree fully via Alt-click

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
It would be nice to have a feature where you could <kbd>alt+click</kbd> on a folder and all of its subfolders (recursive) would either expand/collapse based on the clicked folder.
- [ ] If I <kbd>alt+click</kbd> on a collapsed folder, the current folder and it's sub-folders will expand (recursive)
- [x] If I <kbd>alt+click</kbd> on a expanded folder, the current folder and it's sub-folders will collapse (recursive) (this is covered and supported via https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/32550)

data.title: Jsx formatter inserts extra space in code block if last character is a right paren
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.3.1 (e6b4afa53e9c0f54edef1673de9001e9f0f547ae, 2016-07-12T13:35:06.227Z) - OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.10586 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open VSCode (with no folders open). 2. Create a new blank file and save as 'test.jsx'. 3. Enter the following into the file: `
{new Date().toDateString()}
`. 4. Format the file. 5. The text will be altered to: `
{new Date().toDateString() }
`. This also happens with JSX embedded in regular js files, the above is simply the most straightforward way of reproducing the problem.

data.title: Highlight changed files in a Git repo when folder is open in the Explorer view
data.body:
- VSCode Version: any
- OS Version: any

If you open a folder in the Explorer view, and the folder is part of a Git repo, highlight files that have changes that are uncommitted. Atom Editor does that today and it adds tremendous value to the workflow.

data.title: Support Need to create an app on the same UI model which VSCode uses
data.body:
Hi,

We have an app which was using V8 and now we started to switch to ChakraCore, so delighted... Our previous app was on Windows only and was using C#.

Now, we want to it to be portable on Mac and Linux. Since, we can see the VS code works on all platforms, can you please give us a hint how to use same application development model and UI which same crossplatform, which is being used for VSCode.

I appreciate, if some links or guide is provided...

Thanks

data.title: Opening a browser window from an extension
data.body: I am looking to open a browser window from an extension but it doesn't look like `shell.openExternal` is exposed in the extensions framework.  `shell` is from the `electron` package. Is there another way to open a browser window from an extension or does some work need to be done to expose shell.openExternal`?

data.title: Lower case drive letter in Open New Command Prompt command on Windows
data.body:
BUG REPRO HERE: https://github.com/rob3c/tsc-tsnode-vscode-casing-bug-on-windows
## Overview

Starting with the 2016-07-14 release of Visual Studio Code Insiders edition (and now released in regular VS Code 1.3.1), the behavior of the _Open New Command Prompt_ command (`ctrl+shift+C`) changed on Windows. Now, it lower-cases the drive letter in the new console's prompt, and that seems to affect the ability of at least `ts-node` (and possibly other tools) to build typescript code when the `forceConsistentCasingInFileNames` compiler option is set in _tsconfig.json_.
## Step 1 - Open two command prompts for comparison
- Within VS Code, invoke the `Open New Command Prompt` command via `ctrl+shift+C` (or find it using _View | Command Palette..._ in the menu). Notice that the drive letter in the prompt is lower case now!
- Open a standard Windows Command Prompt outside of VS Code in the normal way, and navigate to this project's root folder. Notice that the standard console has a captial drive letter.
## Step 2 - create some source files

```
// tsconfig.json
{
    "compilerOptions": {
        "forceConsistentCasingInFileNames": true,
        "module": "commonjs",
        "moduleResolution": "node",
        "outDir": "bin",
        "target": "es5"
    },
    "exclude": [
        "bin",
        "node_modules"
    ]
}
```

```
// foo.ts
export class Foo {
    constructor(public bar: string) {}
}
```

```
// index.ts
import { Foo } from './foo';
let foo = new Foo('bar');
console.log(JSON.stringify(foo));
```
## Step 3 - Build successfully using typescript directly

```
> tsc
```

This builds successfully in both command prompt windows.
## Step 4 - Break stuff!

```
> ts-node index.ts
```

This builds and runs successfully in the standard Windows command prompt that has an upper-case drive letter, but it breaks in the console window that VS Code opens with this error:

```
C:\dev\bug-repros\tsc-tsnode-vscode-casing-bug-on-windows\node_modules\ts-node\src\index.ts:280
        throw new TSError(diagnosticList)
              ^
TSError: ? Unable to compile TypeScript
index.ts (1,21): File name 'C:/dev/bug-repros/tsc-tsnode-vscode-casing-bug-on-windows/foo.ts' differs from already included file name 'c:/dev/bug-repros/tsc-tsnode-vscode-casing-bug-on-windows/foo.ts' only in casing (1149)
    at getOutput (C:\dev\bug-repros\tsc-tsnode-vscode-casing-bug-on-windows\node_modules\ts-node\src\index.ts:280:15)
    at compile (C:\dev\bug-repros\tsc-tsnode-vscode-casing-bug-on-windows\node_modules\ts-node\src\index.ts:289:14)
    at loader (C:\dev\bug-repros\tsc-tsnode-vscode-casing-bug-on-windows\node_modules\ts-node\src\index.ts:304:23)
    at Object.require.extensions.(anonymous function) [as .ts] (C:\dev\bug-repros\tsc-tsnode-vscode-casing-bug-on-windows\node_modules\ts-node\src\index.ts:321:14)
    at Module.load (module.js:458:32)
    at tryModuleLoad (module.js:417:12)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:409:3)
    at Function.Module.runMain (module.js:575:10)
    at Object.<anonymous> (C:\dev\bug-repros\tsc-tsnode-vscode-casing-bug-on-windows\node_modules\ts-node\src\_bin.ts:172:12)
    at Module._compile (module.js:541:32)
```

BUG REPRO HERE: https://github.com/rob3c/tsc-tsnode-vscode-casing-bug-on-windows

data.title: Keyboard shortcuts not visible in menu on Ubuntu

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.3.1 (e6b4afa53e9c0f54edef1673de9001e9f0f547ae, 2016-07-12T13:28:46.761Z)
- OS Version: Ubuntu Linux Xenial Xerus (16.04), with Linux x64 4.4.0-28-generic

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Start Visual Studio Code on Ubuntu
2. Open a menu, e.g. View
3. Notice that key bindings/shortcuts are not shown after each item.

Even though the shortcuts are not shown, they do work normally.

Other programs on Ubuntu (e.g. the file manager) show shortcuts as grey text beside the menu item label.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5021259/16924803/5436b4ba-4d21-11e6-90f1-3a78cd26ee11.png)
